title: A $111 carbon tax in Australia would still be too low, says IMF
text:
The fund says to limit global warming to 2°C or less—the level deemed safe by science—large emitting countries need to take ambitious action by introducing a carbon tax set to rise quickly to $US75 a tonne in 2030.

But it admits that in fossil-fuel rich countries including Australia, that price would not be enough to meet the federal government's commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions 26–28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030.

"Governments will need to increase the price of carbon emissions to give people and firms incentives to reduce energy use and shift to clean energy sources."

"Carbon taxes are the most powerful and efficient tools, but only if they are implemented in a fair and growth-friendly way.

"Whereas a $25 a ton price would be more than enough for some countries (for example, China, India, and Russia) to meet their Paris Agreement pledges, in other cases (for example, Australia and Canada) even the $75 a ton carbon tax falls short," the IMF notes."

The Coalition government abolished Labor's carbon price.

The Morrison government is paying for the Snowy 2.0 expansion in NSW, planning to underwrite more hydro power in Tasmania and threatening "big stick" legislation to potentially break up energy companies.

Businesses such as BHP and energy companies want a simple carbon price in order to give investment certainty, but have been frustrated by the Coalition government's refusal.

Coalition conservatives last year blocked the Turnbull government's proposed compromise option, the National Energy Guarantee, for the power sector.

Energy Minister Angus Taylor recently said the Coalition government abolished Labor's carbon tax because electricity prices went up after it was introduced.

"The point of emissions trading schemes in the past has often been to raise the price of energy, or typically always been to raise the price of energy so people consume less. We're taking a different approach," Mr Taylor said.

In a separate report by the Washington-based global economic institution, it also appeared to demur from the Morrison government's push for business to stick to its knitting of traditional business and economic matters and not waste time so-called "virtue signalling" on social issues.

"Environmental, social, and governance issues can have a material impact on firms’ performance and on the stability of the financial system more broadly," the IMF says.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison last week criticised unaccountable global institutions for trying to impose rules on Australia's sovereignty.

Meanwhile, the then head of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, Martin Parkinson warned in July that Australians will continue to suffer high power prices because of the failure to impose an economy-wide carbon price on emissions.

"Until we have a sensible set of policies that can be sustained in the long run, then we will have prices above what we need to have," he said.

Dr Parkinson, an economist who has been involved in energy and climate policy since the Howard government's preparations for an emissions trading scheme (ETS) in 2007, said an "explicit price on carbon" through an emissions trading scheme would be cheaper than other mechanisms like the current Renewable Energy Target.
description: A rising carbon tax to $US75 a tonne would still not be enough for Australia to meet its Paris emissions reduction target, the International Monetary Fund says.
